newsitem.title: FRANCE: Brunei seeks French business, promotes eco-tourism.
newsitem.headline: Brunei seeks French business, promotes eco-tourism.

text.p: Tiny oil-rich sultanate Brunei is seeking to attract French businesses and promote its unspoilt rainforest as a key destination for "eco-tourism," Brunei's minister for industry and primary resources said on Wednesday.

Brunei was making "determined efforts to encourage diversification within the economy. The oil and gas will not last forever," Pehin Haji Abdul Rahman Taib told reporters. He was accompanying the Sultan of Brunei on his first state visit to France.
The Sultan earlier met French President Jacques Chirac and discussed ways of expanding bilateral economic cooperation, particularly in trade and investment, the minister said.
Brunei is seeking to attract direct foreign investment in high technology, food processing and tourism, he said.

The tourism drive, however, will be selective, in keeping with Brunei's conservation policy of its rainforests. It was "only one of the few countries to preserve the (rainforest) habitat," unlike others which exploited it for timber, he said.
Brunei wanted to tap some of the flow of tourists from countries in the Asia/Pacific region such as Taiwan, Japan, Hong Kong, who currently go to nearby destinations such as Malaysia.
"Why don't we take some of them?" he asked.

The Brunei delegation was also meeting heads of French companies in a bid to attract foreign firms. It wants to draw small and medium-sized companies, not only to invest directly, but to tap the highly-educated local population.
But as Brunei's domestic population represents a tiny market of 280,000, it is marketing itself as a launchpad for the Asia/Pacific region.

"Our ambition is to develop Brunei as a gateway to the world's most dynamic economic region. ASEAN has a population of 420 million, with GNP of more than $600 billion and annual economic growth of eight percent," he said.
It has set up the China Infrastructure Development Fund, in which two large French firms, aluminium group Pechiney SA and cement maker Lafarge SA are involved.

Brunei, which is a member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) defence grouping and Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, could act as a matchmaker between French and Asian companies.

The existance of such regional groupings should defuse conflicts in the area, Abdul Rahman Taib said and the present trend in heavy military spending reflected affluence and a replacement need, not than hostile intentions.
